events.description: The first internet connections in Guatemala were primarily available through academic and government institutions.
The first commercial ISPs started emerging, providing dial-up internet access.
The General Telecommunications Law was enacted, privatizing the telecommunications sector.
Guatel, the state-owned telecom company, was privatized and later became Telgua.
Telefónica entered the Guatemalan market, offering dial-up internet through Movistar.
Telgua was acquired by América Móvil and introduced broadband internet under the Claro brand.
WiMAX technology expanded internet access to rural areas.
Claro became the dominant ISP after merging Telgua’s services.
Cable internet providers like Tigo (Millicom) began expanding broadband services.
4G LTE networks were introduced, improving mobile internet speeds.
Several ISPs started offering fiber optic broadband in major cities.
New regulations encouraged competition, leading to lower prices and improved speeds.
América Móvil (Claro) acquired Telefónica Movistar in Guatemala.
COVID-19 pandemic increased demand for internet services, expanding coverage.
The first satellite internet services, including Starlink, were introduced.
Companies like Kingo started providing prepaid solar-powered internet access to rural areas.
